section.p: The use-case is that you need to include some external data that is supplied as CSV file. This might be the case when the file is generated automatically – e.g. as some kind of report – or it is generated by hand from people without the skills and/or tools to create DITA content.
The first line of the CSV table will be treated as header. The column count of the table is the maximal number of entries in any row of the file.

There is some special handling required to deal with quotation marks, newlines and semicolons. To be able to display the newlines within a simple table the XSLT script the attribute xml:space is set to "preserve". An alternative would be to create a table element instead of simpletable and create a p element for each line.
